page.title: 12HAZELBANK BRIDLEPATH
page.content: The argument over the{right of way from Hazelbank to Waterston began early in 1984. This path is one of the few remaining public{bridlepaths.}The owner of the land erected a kissing- gate and a barbed wire fence. He claimed that horses had been jumping there, but this was denied and the users of the path removed any obstructions. Another complaint was that lost horseshoes may damage farm machinery - this would not occur if the farmer had left the hedge which formed a lane beside the field; he had cut it down to increase his acreage. Several public meetings later and after the intervention of the Horse Society the farmer{re-opened}the bridlepath 8 months after its closure. The farmer still plants crops across the path. by Andrea Babb
